text:
Warning! Do NOT buy a low end open frame uv diode laser.   I bought one and the laser kept lighting the material on fire. Because I had to constantly watch out for fires I damaged my eyesight permanently even with safety glasses on.   

No deal is ever worth your eyesight!!!

Buy an enclosed laser with enough power to cut through the material. Gas assist lasers will prevent fires.  

Again stay away from uv lasers they’re only really good for engraving on wood not cutting anything.

text:
I'm sticking with my Atomstack pre-order for my first CO2 laser. The PS2 has some nice features, but for the lower price, red dot alignment & full Lightburn support is my main reason (the PS2 & S in Lightburn doesn't support camera or auto-focus).

The pull-out fan is handy but probably easy to swap on Hurricane and won't be often. The simple filter on the PS2 was a nice touch but will probably look at adding some strip magnets and fan mesh to the Atomstack for the same effect when it arrives.
video: Why is xTool so Popular - The P2S Desktop Laser Re

text: Great video but your Etsy fees are way low.  Yeah, it's 6.5% transaction fee but also a 3% processing fee.  If the order comes in via their "Offsite Ads" then it's another 12% off the entire order including shipping.  That's 21.5% and I think I'm missing one off the top of my head as I had figured it up in the "worst case scenario" with an order with Offsite Ads at almost 25%.  Since you don't know when those sales happen or have any visibility to how they happen, you have to be prepared for them.

text:
Does this "smart align - take an image and get a proper placement on the material" really work?
I have tried so many times to use various cameras with Lightburn (Atomstack x20 pro, including the original Atomstack camera kit) to place content precisely - it's ALWAYS disappointing. 

Not only for the obvious reasons: 
If you use material with different thickness, you need to re-calibrate. 
And it's really hard to mount a camera over a laser in a consistent spot: all constructins I have seen with beams and tripods and "mount to a lid" just didn't have the accuracy required for it to be useful. The camera will always move a tiny bit out of calibration.
Not only that, but even if you really mount it as sturdy as possible and have the same thickness of material all the time, it will just by itself loose calibration within 2-3 runs.
Not only that, even if you use fixed jigs (no camera), the laser itself isn't consistent in positioning, you may get 2-5mm shifts randomly.

So all in all the Lightburn camera alignment feature is just a collosal disappointment.

Is that what you show in the video - randomly positioned material with accurate detection and accurate positioning - REALLY REALLY reality or is that staged B.S.? Does it REALLY get the content onto the material in the right angle, in the right place?
Can there be a proper review of this feature, please?

Thanks!
video: Why is xTool so Popular - The P2S Desktop Laser Re

text: IT is in the settings.  Go to XCS with the machine connected. The little gear icon next to the machine name - click on that. Scroll down and there are different settings for Cut and Engrave.  But still can't go down to 0% for either of them.

text: Buy a cheap Chinese diode, a Good (like OMTech) Fiber and a decent (80watts or more) CO2. Yeah 3 lasers... and while there's a lot of crossover in capabilities, you don't want to use your CO2 (tube replacement is expensive) or fiber for stuff your diode can do.

text:
Please stop referring to the Xtool F1 as a fibre laser.  It's an IR & visible light diode galvo machine.  Xtool muddied the water by marketing it as a fibre, then wondered why people were annoyed by the misrepresentation.
The F1 Ultra, however, *is* a fibre laser.

text:
Snapmaker 2.0 falls into the "tricked out 3D printer" category, along with the diode modules you install in your 3D printer.
Again no M1 on the list, which is still a viable choice for crafters
Snapmaker Ray 40 is in the wrong category, it's an open frame with optional enclosure.

The open frame category is designed for a low upfront cost and not meant to be used as they are but be equipped with accessories later.

The "desktop diode" category has branched in two directions: one is the crafter category (M1, M1 Ultra, WeCreat, Flux Ador, Aura, Spark) and one is hobby/workshop (S1, Falcon2 Pro, Roly, Genmitsu S8). The crafter machines are getting multifunctional with printing/blade cutting modules, while the hobby ones focus on lasers.

Instead of having an always ticked "enclosure" column, you should add important parameters missing from your sheet:
* how the focus works: by moving the module or bed - as this limits functionality, you can't easily do curved surface processing when the whole bed has to move up and down
* rotary attachment support - out of the box, with optional riser base, etc.
* pass through / removable bottom plate

BTW as far as I know WeCreat somehow shot off xTool (ex employees?) - their software is basically a clone of xCS 1.x.
BTW2 you could have waited with this until the P2S review.
video: Watch This Before Buying a Laser Cutter & Engraver

text: It's not the total watts, but pulse width, pulse rate, M2 value to maximize your total energy at the focus. So if 40 watt has 100 um spot and the 20 watt has 40 um spot. The 20 watt is going to crush the 40 watt. Also anything over 0.5 watts is a class 4 laser.

text: The more diodelasers are stacked, the more semi-transparent mirrors the beam has to go through and thus the more scattered the beam gets (polution in the mirrors). So the beam isn't as crisp as with one laser (i.e. lower power)

These will vary in size but initial will be about 1-2mm thick with white foreground and black letters.  Some will need to use a very small font (probably 4-8 if possible) while larger ones will be 24-28 font.  For the smaller there will be up to 50 per sheet so it will also need to cut them out.  TIA
